11:18 am
BE11:18am

[The ECJ] indication] makes “no deal” significantly less likely. The circumstances around a “no deal” Brexit always looked rather specific, and required that the House of Commons was not sufficiently unified to prevent a pro-Brexit PM moving down this path. The possibility of revoking Article 50 potentially gives the Commons both an ability to (a) stop the Brexit process and (b) do so without removing the PM via a confidence vote (or other forms of pressure). At this point in time, there is some ambiguity about exactly where the right of revocation in the UK would lie. But, given the way in which the Supreme Court justified the need for an Act of Parliament in order to notify of the intent to withdraw, it looks very likely to us that this would ultimately be a right of Parliament rather than the executive. Perhaps Gina Miller or others already have a legal case to establish this clearly in mind.

BE11:19am

Second, it makes “no Brexit (at least for now)” more likely. One of the issues about a second referendum has, in our view, always been the need for an Article 50 extension and potential EU involvement in the design of that referendum. The UK now appears to have the option of revoking unilaterally and taking a period of time of its own choosing to decide what happens next. That time could be used to hold a second referendum on terms entirely decided by the UK. It could also, or alternatively, be used to establish a different approach to a withdrawal negotiation before notifying of the intent to withdraw once again. That could be a more aggressive Brexiteer-inspired approach to the negotiations, or a pivot toward“Norway plus”, for example. And regardless of the initial intent among politicians as the Article 50 notification was revoked, subsequent political events could push the UK onto a different path (for example, what happens if the Government suffers a vote of no confidence or two-thirds of MPs vote for an early election after a revocation). Note also that a decision to revoke the Article 50 notification does not necessarily mean that a subsequent renotification and exit from the EU would take a minimum of two years. If the withdrawal agreement terms were settled quickly after a subsequent renotification, it could set an earlier date for the UK’s exit. The text of Article 50 explicitly allows the withdrawal agreement to set either an earlier or later date than two years from notification for the exit.

Flaneur @Tonald - isnt that just a euphemism for a sterling collapse?
BE11:19am

Third, the ability to withdraw the Article 50 notification unilaterally gives the UK alternatives to exiting underthe terms of the withdrawal agreement that we did not anticipate it would have. Without that right, it looked likely to us that the EU would continue to exert pressure on the UK to accept the Withdrawal Agreement that has been negotiated with the threat of a “no deal” Brexit looming in the background. The EU had a degree of control of the “no deal” risk by the possibility of offering a last minute extension of Article 50 to the UK if that pressure was unsuccessful. However, now the balance of “control” around the Article 50 ‘deadline’ looks more equal, as the UK has the possibility of unilateral revocation in its back pocket should negotiations “go to the wire”. In our view, that serves to both (a) make acceptance of the existing withdrawal agreement less likely, and (b) raises the possibility of both the UK’s internal political wrangling over Brexit, and its attempts to negotiate with the EU, extending further into 2019. We had previously thought that the pressure of a potential “no deal” and the need to complete legislative procedures ahead of a March exit would force a resolution of the UK’s domestic position on Brexit by the end of January, but it now looks more likely that could persist for longer.

IslandDweller probabilities to 10-50-40I'm not often in a bookies, but haven't the bookies change their odds to suggest they expect second vote
11:19 am
BE11:19am

All of which is kinda consensus now, I guess. Here's the upshot.

BE11:19am

We take the probability of “no deal” in the first half of 2019 down from 20% to 10%. We take the probability of an orderly negotiated Brexit down from 60% to 50%. And we push the possibility of “no Brexit” up from 20% to 40%. Taken together, that means a 60-40 call on Brexit occurring in the first half of 2019, as opposed to 80-20 previously. Within the “no Brexit” scenarios, a unilateral revocation on the UK’s part looks more likely to us than a joint UK-EU decision to extend the Article 50 negotiating period and thereby keep the existing clock running. And a second referendum strikes us as rather more likely than a general election to be driving a decision to revoke. Hence, within that 40% “no Brexit” possibility, we see a 25% chance of a revocation to facilitate a second referendum, and a 15% chance that it is to facilitate a general election.

The Debate, Bull; strategic investments are on track, SDIs are now being considered, the Airline continues to deliver in a challenging environment, online momentum continues and Sten Daugaard (interim CFO) coming onboard, versus Bear; balance sheet uncertainty,
higher SDIs in FY18, cash flow supported by working capital inflows, vague guidance given uncertainties and a reversal of Thomas Cook's UK retail store closure programme.

11:30 am
BE11:30am

On balance, risk is assymetric: Although we acknowledge the risk, our central thesis is that Thomas Cook can avoid a capital raise given; its unconditional extended flexibility regarding bank covenants for 1Q/2Q FY19E, progress on profitability going forward given strategic initiatives and capacity cuts, a possible stake sale in its Airline which we estimate to be worth £1.1bn EV, and a dislocation between what we estimate leverage (as per its RCF leverage covenant) was before its 2013 rights issue and what we estimate it will be in 1Q19E, c25%+ lower.
We cut our forecasts by -10% for operating profit in FY19E, which includes c-3.5% bookings YoY for the Tour Operator, as it pulls back capacity. We forecast c£100m of SDIs (Separately disclosed items) in FY19E, versus management guidance of £75-100m.
Risks: Whilst our central thesis does not assume any, we acknowledge the risk of a dilutive capital raise and of balance sheet concern contagion to the consumer franchise. Other risks include index exclusion and impacting profitability; demand, Brexit, another hot summer, fuel volatility and FX.

Pharma @wayneJ - it's not a law court and there are no proceedings - just an instruction to publish the legal advice, which the government is now doing.
BE11:30am

And on valuation .....

BE11:30am

We continue to value on a recovered EPS basis, but now use reported vs adjusted EPS. We value FY21E EPS on a 9.6x P/E, for a Fair Value of 49p, discounted back. PT 43p, reiterate Buy. Thomas Cook trades on 2.8x FY19E P/E, a 69% discount to tour operator peers versus a 3yr average discount of 35%.

BE11:32am

Management now guides to 1Q19 u/ling EBIT to be broadly flat versus the prior year, having previously expected a deterioration (unquantified). This has been enabled by a mid-double digit opex saving, which leads management to guide to cash consumption of c.£1.1-1.2bn in 1Q19 and therefore Dec18 Net Debt of c.£1.4-1.5bn (in line with our prior Base
and Bear case). Consequently, we believe that for the group to have "re-set" its covenants with its lenders to generate c.20% headroom in Q1/Q2 FY19, it will have required a c.1.0x relaxation from its last disclosed leverage covenants (AR15), which is not inconceivable. More importantly, its liquidity position remains intact according to our analysis. We estimate liquidity headroom of c.£750m in Dec18 (from c.£830m previously). Therefore, without a call on its cash by suppliers or a material worsening in demand (Brexit/recession), the group should not need an equity event, in our view.

BE11:42am

Interim results were better than expected, primarily due to a higher profit contribution from the rail division. Interim revenues declined 31% to £1,230.8m, primarily reflecting the loss of the SWT rail franchise. Like-for-like revenue growth in UK bus (regional) was 3.4% and LFL London bus revenues increased by 0.2%. As expected, group operating profit fell to £103.4m (from £114.8m), with improvements in UK regional bus but weakness elsewhere. Adjusted EPS fell 5% to 12.9p, benefiting from a lower tax charge. The closing net debt increased from £395.8m in April 2018 to £461.2m in October 2018. The Board has declared an unchanged interim dividend of 3.8p.

The rail division is expected to remain profitable in H2 with continuing good profitability at East Midlands. As a result, the company has increased its expectation of full-year adjusted EPS to reflect the above-forecast interim rail earnings.

Maudise @Excel ignoring the weighting elements of FTSE on USA based or $ traded companies. Depends if your question is actually "Are the UK companies within the FTSE100 good value" or "Is the FTSE100 a safe place if the USA goes mad?"
BE11:42am

And UBS.

11:42 am
BE11:42am

H1 pre-X EBIT was £103.4m (UBSe 94.7m), PBT £87m (78m) and EPS 12.9p (11.3p). The main variance versus our estimates were better than expected rail results, with both the settlement for South West Trains and Virgin West Coast results contributing. How much of this is therefore ongoing is a moot point, given SWT has now ended and the West Coast franchise is currently being re-tendered. Net debt was £463m, also in-line with our expectations.

UK Regional bus showing improvement; London more difficult

The UK regional business continues to show improvement, with revenue per vehicle mile +4.4%, revenue per journey +4.3% on capacity 0.9% lower than last year. H1 benefited from good weather and rail replacement work and thus revenue growth is expected to moderate in H2. London bus remains difficult, with tender results disappointing and a re-evaluation of bid models and costs. TfL is planning on reducing bus capacity, which may result in further pressure.

US goodwill impaired; outlook generally stable

On the back of a more competitive US coach market, Stagecoach has impaired £85.4m of goodwill. With the exception of an improved performance from UK rail, SGC's earnings outlook for FY2019 remains unchanged.

Structural headwinds remain across the business, but we expect to see further evidence of management action to mitigate these. A goodwill impairment has been booked for North America, alongside a strategic review that could result in a full or partial sale of that business. The lowly valuation reflects the challenges, but not the potential for management to address them. Our recommendation remains BUY with a 175p SOTP-based TP.

BE12:00pm

Here's Morgan Stanley selling Hargreaves.

12:00 pm
Hargreaves Lansdown PLC (HL.:LSE): Last: 1,913, down 66 (-3.34%), High: 1,960, Low: 1,868, Volume: 323.32k
BE12:01pm

We continue to view HL as a premier franchise and long term winner from structural changes, e.g. regulation (RDR) and the move from DB to DC. However, with the stock now trading on ~26.5x CY20e P/E, vs. EU asset managers on ~10-11x and Charles Schwab on ~14x, future growth is well captured. We believe the wide cone of potential outcomes (risk/reward) is being under appreciated, and while we increase our bull case by 12% (owing to higher rates), this is not enough to compensate for the issues we highlight below, which lead us to cut our bear case by 50%. We believe bullish assumptions are required to turn buyers / see upside to the current share price and on balance see the risk/reward as no longer compelling at current valuations - prefer Overweight-rated Amundi & SLA amongst asset managers.

BE12:01pm

The issues they highlight below are Hargreaves own-brand funds sucking.

Tom Dalgleish Would Trump be engineering a slowdown under the guise of stalling a China trade deal to allow an upswing approaching his presidential re-election
12:01 pm
BE12:01pm

The success of HL's own branded funds, which drove above-market, higher-margin growth over the last few years, may be at risk of a reversal given concentration risks and poor performance in the underlying funds. Our bear case assumes half of customers switch to another fund on the platform and fees are reduced by 50% for the remaining customers – worth ~14% to FY20 PBT;

BE12:02pm

.... plus ISA market share topping out, plus Lloyds and Revolut arriving with their US-style pricing

BE12:02pm

Plus costs becoming harder to cut due to PSD2 and competition from the banks.

12:03 pm
BE12:03pm

You still get crazy earnings growth tho, thanks to the BOE.

BE12:03pm

We put through 5 rate hikes out to end 2020, consistent with our UK economists' view. This drives overall group earnings CAGR of ~22% FY19-22e vs. 13% previously - with every 25bps move a +/- 8% impact on PBT. We continue to value HL using a DCF, though the earnings changes above plus the lower cost of equity we ascribe in our base case (from 10% to 9% given option to raise low cost debt, high FCF and dividend payout) drive a 7% increase in our price target to £18.70.
